texts.shortText:
Small, transparent, white or pink leech with a sucker at each end. Body smooth, the anterior part narrowly extended and with four red eye-spots arranged in a square at the head (not visible in preserved material). Posterior half of body elongate-oval.

Also easily recognized by its habit of living on the bodies of rockâ€“lobsters, particularly on the abdomen and pleopods.
Body length typically 4 mm, but up to 9 mm.

Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.

A long-known but only recently formally described species associated with rock-lobsters and presumed to feed on their blood. Usually found on the abdomen and particularly on the pleopods. Often numerous leeches present on each host.
Probably feeds on the blood of the rock-lobster Jasus lalandii although some leeches found on crustaceans do also feed on the blood of fishes.

Little is known about reproduction in this group, but leeches are hermaphrodites and although some brood their young, most lay their eggs in a cocoon attached to the favoured substratum, in this case probably the host.

Very few marine leeches have been reported from South Africa and this is the only species known to occur on rock-lobsters. The smooth, transparent body, 4 red eye spots (not visible in preserved specimens) and narrow anterior extension of the body are characteristic features. It is presumed here that the species described by Utevsky is indeed the same as that previously reported from this host by Day and by Branch et al. The descriptions of body form are similar, although Utevsky reports the eyes being absent in preserved specimens and these are clearly visible in the live image in Branch et al. It is common for eye pigments to disappear in alcohol though, so this is probably a function of  the description being based only on preserved material.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64, as Heloblella sp.).

Day, JH (1969). A guide to marine life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town (p. 67, as Helobdella)

Utevsky, AY (2004). A new species of marine leeches (Hirudinea, Piscicolidae) from the coastal waters of South Africa. Vestnik Zoologii, 38(5), 79-83.
